The codomain of a function is the set that contains all potential output values, even if some of those values are not actually produced by any input in the domain.
Two cycles $(x_{1}, \ldots, x_{r})$ and $(y_{1}, \ldots, y_{s})$ are called disjoint if the sets $\{x_{1}, \ldots, x_{r}\}$ and $\{y_{1}, \ldots, y_{s}\}$ have no elements in common.
Does the concept of a/an Codomain need to be defined for a definition of a/an Disjoint Cycles to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation:
The concept of disjoint cycles involves two cycles, each represented as a sequence of elements, and these cycles are considered disjoint if the sets of elements in each cycle have no overlap. This definition focuses solely on the elements within each cycle and their relationships to each other, specifically whether they share any elements or not.

The concept of a codomain, on the other hand, pertains to functions and describes the set of all possible outputs a function can have, regardless of whether all these outputs are achieved by the function from its domain. This concept is related to the mapping of elements from one set to another but does not directly influence the definition or understanding of disjoint cycles.

Therefore, understanding or defining disjoint cycles does not require the concept of a codomain. Disjoint cycles can be fully understood and defined using only the notion of sets and elements within those sets, without any reference to functions or their codomains.
